benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/xml - Retrieve the full catalog as XML

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (latest catalog, by requestedDate, by accountId, by both) verify 200 responses and Content-Type text/xml.

Query Parameters: Positive and negative parameter combinations covered — valid requestedDate/accountId, non-matching requestedDate, invalid formats, maximum lengths (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC06, TC07, TC08, TC16).
Empty/No-Data Responses: Scenarios exist for no catalog at all and for an empty catalog structure (TC05, TC15).
Authorization & Permissions: Unauthorized and forbidden cases are covered (TC10, TC11).
Error Handling: Error scenarios for dependency failure, timeout, malformed input, and injection attempts are present (TC12, TC22, TC13).
Robustness & Resilience: Tests for transient network recovery, concurrency, large payloads/data, regression for malformed XML, and performance under load are included (TC14, TC17, TC18, TC19, TC21).
Backward Compatibility & Accessibility: Tests for backward compatibility and accessibility (if UI displays XML) are included (TC20, TC23, TC24).
gaps: Pagination: No test cases for pagination/streaming or behavior when the catalog is large enough to require paging (guideline: Pagination).
Caching Behavior / Conditional Requests: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional GET behavior (304 Not Modified).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit rate-limiting tests (e.g., 429 responses under throttling) — load and peak scenarios exist but not rate-limit enforcement checks.

Content Negotiation / Accept header handling: No tests validating server response when Accept header is missing/requests non-XML (e.g., Accept: application/json) or when multiple media types are provided.

Explicit schema validation: Although well-formed XML and compatibility are covered, there are no explicit tests validating the response against a definitive XML schema/XSD to ensure structural correctness beyond well-formedness.

Precise Error Code Expectations: Some negative scenarios accept either 400 or 404/400 — the story expects >=400; tests should assert the exact/canonical error code and error payload format expected by the API contract.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create scenarios where the catalog size triggers pagination or streaming and validate proper paging parameters, links, and behaviors.
Add caching/conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Last-Modified headers, conditional GET returning 304, and Cache-Control behavior.
Add rate limiting tests: simulate rapid repeated requests to assert 429 responses or configured throttling behavior and validate Retry-After header handling.

Add content negotiation tests: assert behavior for various Accept headers (Accept: text/xml, Accept: application/json, missing Accept) and ensure server honors or rejects unsupported media types correctly.
Add XML schema validation: validate returned XML against the official catalog XSD (or schema) to catch structural regressions beyond well-formedness.

Tighten error assertions: convert “404 or 400” style expectations into precise, contract-driven assertions (preferred single canonical code and error response format) or add tests that confirm the API follows documented error conventions.

Add tests for conditional rejection of unknown/extra params if applicable: TC09 currently expects the server to ignore extra params — include tests that confirm documented behavior (ignore vs reject).
